name: Abdominal Crunch
description: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet on the floor. Place hands across chest or behind ears. Contract your abs to lift your shoulders off the floor, then lower with control.
formTips: Focus on using your abdominals to lift your upper body
Keep movement slow and controlled
Maintain space between chin and chest
Keep lower back pressed into the floor
commonMistakes: Pulling on the neck
Using momentum instead of abdominal control
Lifting too high off the ground
Holding breath during exertion
benefits: Strengthens the rectus abdominis (six-pack muscles)
Improves core stability and posture
Helps develop muscular endurance in the abdominal region
Can alleviate certain types of lower back pain
breathingPattern: Exhale as you curl up, inhale as you lower back down
preparationSteps: Lie on your back on a mat
Bend your knees with feet flat on the floor
Place your hands across your chest or lightly behind your ears
Ensure your lower back is in contact with the floor

name: Bicycle Crunch
description: Lie on your back with hands behind head and knees lifted. Bring opposite elbow to knee while extending the other leg straight, then switch sides in a pedaling motion.
formTips: Keep lower back pressed into the floor
Touch elbow to knee by rotating your torso
Control the movement - quality over speed
Extend the opposite leg fully but hover it above the ground
commonMistakes: Rushing through repetitions
Pulling on the neck
Lifting shoulders instead of rotating torso
Allowing lower back to arch off the floor
benefits: Engages both the rectus abdominis and obliques simultaneously
Improves core rotation and stability
Enhances coordination between upper and lower body
Greater activation of abs compared to traditional crunches
breathingPattern: Exhale as you bring elbow to knee, inhale as you extend, maintain rhythm with movement
preparationSteps: Lie on your back on a mat
Lift your knees to a 90-degree angle (tabletop position)
Place your hands lightly behind your head with elbows wide
Slightly lift your head and shoulders off the mat

name: Straight Arm Plank
description: Hold a push-up position with your weight on your hands and toes. Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels.
formTips: Keep your hips in line with shoulders and ankles
Engage your core by pulling your navel to your spine
Look slightly ahead to maintain neutral neck position
Push the ground away with your hands to engage shoulders
commonMistakes: Dropping or raising hips
Holding breath
Shoulders hunched around ears
Sagging in the middle or piking hips
regressionExercises: incline plank on bench or wall
benefits: Strengthens core without spinal flexion
Improves posture and spinal alignment
Engages multiple muscle groups simultaneously
Develops isometric strength and endurance
Helps reduce lower back pain
breathingPattern: Maintain normal, steady breathing throughout hold - avoid shallow breathing
preparationSteps: Start in a push-up position with hands directly under shoulders
Extend legs straight behind you, resting on balls of feet
Set your feet hip-width apart for stability
Engage core and glutes before beginning the hold

name: Russian Twist
description: Sit on the floor with knees bent and feet slightly lifted. Lean back at a 45-degree angle, then rotate your torso from side to side while keeping your core engaged.
formTips: Keep your back straight throughout the movement
Rotate from your core, not just your arms
Touch the ground beside your hip on each side if possible
Keep feet elevated for increased difficulty
commonMistakes: Rounding the back
Moving arms without rotating the torso
Using momentum instead of controlled movement
Not twisting far enough to engage obliques properly
benefits: Strengthens the obliques and rotational core muscles
Improves torso mobility and rotational power
Enhances coordination and balance
Helps define the waistline
breathingPattern: Exhale as you rotate to each side, inhale as you return to center
preparationSteps: Sit on a mat with knees bent
Lean back slightly while maintaining a straight back
Lift feet a few inches off the ground
Extend arms forward with hands together or holding a weight

name: Reverse Crunch
description: Lie on your back with knees bent at 90 degrees. Using your lower abs, lift your hips off the floor by bringing your knees toward your chest, then lower with control.
formTips: Focus on using lower abs to initiate the movement
Keep the movement controlled and avoid using momentum
Press lower back into the floor throughout the exercise
Keep upper body relaxed with shoulders down
commonMistakes: Using momentum or swinging legs
Lifting hips too high causing back strain
Moving too quickly through the motion
Not fully engaging lower abs
benefits: Targets the lower portion of the abdominals
Strengthens hip flexors while engaging core
Helps improve lower abdominal definition
Low impact on the spine compared to traditional crunches
breathingPattern: Exhale as you lift hips/knees toward chest, inhale as you lower
preparationSteps: Lie on your back on a mat
Bend knees to 90 degrees with feet in the air
Place arms at sides with palms down for stability
Engage core by drawing navel toward spine

name: Leg Drop
description: Lie on your back with legs extended straight up. Keeping one leg up, slowly lower the other leg toward the floor without touching, then switch legs in a controlled motion.
formTips: Keep lower back pressed firmly into the floor throughout
Lower the leg only as far as you can maintain back contact with floor
Keep both legs straight but not locked
Focus on controlled movement rather than speed
commonMistakes: Allowing the lower back to arch off the floor
Dropping the leg too low too quickly
Not maintaining core engagement throughout
Holding breath during the exercise
benefits: Strengthens deep core stabilizers and lower abdominals
Improves core control and stability
Enhances hip flexor strength and control
Teaches proper core bracing techniques
breathingPattern: Exhale as you lower the leg, inhale as you bring it back up
preparationSteps: Lie on your back on a mat
Extend both legs straight up toward ceiling
Place hands under your lower back for support (optional)
Engage your core by drawing navel toward spine

name: Leg In and Out
description: Sit with knees bent and feet slightly off the floor. Lean back slightly to balance, then alternate between extending legs out straight and pulling them back in toward your chest.
formTips: Maintain a slight backward lean throughout the exercise
Keep your back straight, not rounded
Engage your core throughout the entire movement
Keep movements controlled and deliberate
commonMistakes: Rounding the back excessively
Letting legs touch the floor during extension
Using momentum instead of core strength
Leaning too far back, straining the back
regressionExercises: alternating single leg in and out
benefits: Builds core strength and endurance
Improves coordination between upper and lower body
Engages multiple core muscles simultaneously
Helps develop balance and stability
breathingPattern: Exhale as you extend legs out, inhale as you bring them back in
preparationSteps: Sit on a mat with knees bent and feet on the floor
Place hands on the floor slightly behind your hips for support
Lift feet a few inches off the ground
Engage your core and find your balance point

name: Side Crunch
description: Lie on your back with knees bent and dropped to one side. Place hands behind head and crunch up toward the same side, focusing on oblique engagement. Repeat on both sides.
formTips: Keep movement slow and controlled
Focus on lifting with the side of your abdomen
Maintain space between chin and chest
Keep shoulders relaxed, not hunched
commonMistakes: Pulling on the neck
Using momentum instead of oblique strength
Lifting too high and straining neck
Not keeping legs stabilized to one side
benefits: Targets the oblique muscles for waist definition
Improves rotational core strength
Helps create a more balanced core development
Enhances functional movement patterns
breathingPattern: Exhale as you lift and rotate, inhale as you lower back down
preparationSteps: Lie on your back on a mat
Bend knees and let them fall to one side
Place hands lightly behind or beside your head
Ensure your lower back is comfortable in this rotated position

name: Sit Up
description: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat on the floor. With hands across chest or by ears, use your core to lift your entire upper body off the floor to a seated position, then lower back down.
formTips: Keep movement controlled in both directions
Use your core strength, not momentum
Maintain a neutral neck position
Exhale as you rise, inhale as you lower
commonMistakes: Pulling on the neck
Using momentum to swing up
Lifting feet off the ground
Rushing through repetitions
benefits: Strengthens entire abdominal region
Engages hip flexors and lower back
Builds functional core strength
Greater range of motion than crunches
breathingPattern: Exhale as you sit up, inhale as you lower back down
preparationSteps: Lie on your back on a mat
Bend knees with feet flat on the floor, hip-width apart
Cross arms over chest or place hands beside ears
Anchor feet if needed (under a sturdy object or with a partner)

name: V-Up
description: Lie on your back with arms extended overhead and legs straight. Simultaneously lift your arms and legs to create a V-shape with your body, then lower back to starting position.
formTips: Keep movements controlled and deliberate
Try to touch hands to feet at the top of the movement
Keep legs straight but not locked
Focus on using your core to initiate the lift
commonMistakes: Using momentum to swing up
Bending knees excessively
Allowing lower back to arch off the floor
Not reaching full extension at the bottom
benefits: Intensely engages the entire core musculature
Builds strength in hip flexors and lower abs
Improves coordination between upper and lower body
Develops balance and stability
breathingPattern: Exhale as you lift to the V position, inhale as you lower back down
preparationSteps: Lie flat on your back on a mat
Extend legs straight out
Extend arms overhead in line with your body
Engage your core by drawing navel toward spine

name: V Crunch
description: Lie on your back with legs extended and arms along sides. Simultaneously lift your upper body and legs, extending arms parallel to legs to form a V shape, then lower back down.
formTips: Keep your back straight as you lift, not rounded
Reach arms alongside legs, not overhead
Lift shoulders and legs simultaneously
Focus on slow, controlled movements
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of core strength
Allowing legs to bend too much
Straining neck by jutting chin forward
Not engaging abdominals throughout the movement
benefits: Strengthens the entire core in a balanced way
Develops coordination between upper and lower body
Challenges balance and stability
Improves posture by strengthening core stabilizers
breathingPattern: Exhale as you lift into the V position, inhale as you lower back down
preparationSteps: Lie on your back on a mat
Extend legs straight out
Place arms alongside your body, palms down
Engage your core muscles before beginning

name: Plank with Leg Lift
description: Start in a plank position with weight on forearms. While maintaining a stable torso, lift one leg straight up a few inches, hold briefly, then lower and repeat with the other leg.
formTips: Keep hips level and square to the ground as you lift leg
Maintain a strong core and neutral spine throughout
Lift leg only as high as you can while maintaining form
Focus on stability rather than leg height
commonMistakes: Allowing hips to rotate as the leg lifts
Sagging in the middle or piking hips
Holding breath during the exercise
Letting the head drop or neck collapse
progressionExercises: straight arm plank with leg lift
plank with leg and arm lift (opposite sides)
benefits: Challenges core stability in multiple planes
Strengthens hip muscles while engaging core
Improves balance and coordination
Enhances overall core strength and endurance
breathingPattern: Maintain steady breathing throughout, exhale as you lift the leg
preparationSteps: Start in a forearm plank position with elbows under shoulders
Set feet hip-width apart
Engage core and squeeze glutes
Ensure body forms a straight line from head to heels

name: Dead Bug
description: Lie on your back with arms extended toward ceiling and legs in tabletop position. Simultaneously lower opposite arm and leg toward the floor while maintaining lower back contact with the mat, then return to start position.
formTips: Press lower back firmly into the floor throughout
Extend limbs fully without touching the floor
Move slowly and with control
Keep shoulders down away from ears
commonMistakes: Allowing lower back to arch off floor
Moving too quickly, losing core engagement
Not fully extending limbs
Holding breath
benefits: Strengthens deep core muscles while maintaining spine stability
Improves coordination between upper and lower body
Enhances core control and stability
Safe for many with lower back issues when done correctly
contraindications: Shoulder issues that prevent overhead arm position
breathingPattern: Inhale as you extend limbs, exhale as you return to starting position
preparationSteps: Lie on your back on a mat
Bring knees up to tabletop position (90-degree angle)
Extend arms toward ceiling
Press lower back into floor by engaging core

name: Diagonal Plank
description: From a standard plank position, rotate your body to one side, extending the top arm toward the ceiling in a side plank variation, then return to center and repeat on the other side.
formTips: Stack shoulders, hips, and feet when rotated to side
Keep body in straight line throughout entire movement
Rotate from core rather than just arms
Maintain stable shoulder position
commonMistakes: Dropping hips during rotation
Moving too quickly with poor control
Allowing feet to separate during rotation
Collapsing through shoulder
benefits: Challenges core stability in multiple planes
Strengthens obliques and rotational core muscles
Improves shoulder stability and strength
Enhances body control and coordination
breathingPattern: Inhale during center plank, exhale during rotation to side
preparationSteps: Start in forearm plank position with elbows under shoulders
Set feet hip-width apart
Engage core and glutes
Ensure body forms straight line from head to heels

name: Prone Flutter Kick
description: Lie face down with legs extended, arms overhead or by sides. Lift chest and legs slightly off floor, then alternate small kicks with legs while maintaining the lifted position.
formTips: Keep neck in neutral position (look down at mat)
Lift chest and legs only as high as comfortable
Maintain small, controlled kicks
Keep legs relatively straight but not locked
commonMistakes: Lifting head too high causing neck strain
Kicks too large or uncontrolled
Excessive arching of lower back
Holding breath during exercise
benefits: Strengthens posterior chain (back, glutes, hamstrings)
Improves core stability and endurance
Develops lower back strength
Counteracts effects of prolonged sitting
contraindications: Acute lower back pain or injury
breathingPattern: Maintain regular breathing throughout; avoid holding breath
preparationSteps: Lie face down on a mat
Extend legs straight behind you
Place forehead on mat or slightly lifted
Position arms overhead, alongside body, or under forehead

name: Fitball Crunch
description: Sit on a stability ball and walk feet forward until ball is supporting middle/lower back. Place hands behind head and perform a crunch, lifting shoulders off the ball.
formTips: Position ball under mid-back (not lower back or neck)
Keep feet flat on floor, hip-width apart
Maintain neutral neck position (small gap between chin and chest)
Focus on curling ribcage toward pelvis
commonMistakes: Pulling on neck with hands
Positioning ball incorrectly (too high or low)
Using momentum instead of abdominal control
Lifting too high causing lower back strain
benefits: Increases range of motion compared to floor crunches
Engages more stabilizing muscles due to unstable surface
Provides natural back extension at bottom of movement
Reduces pressure on spine compared to floor crunches
breathingPattern: Exhale as you curl up, inhale as you lower back down
preparationSteps: Sit centered on stability ball
Walk feet forward until ball rolls under your mid-back
Position feet flat on floor, hip-width apart
Place hands lightly behind head or crossed over chest

name: Fitball Plank Hold
description: Assume a plank position with forearms on a stability ball instead of the floor. Maintain a straight body line while balancing on the unstable surface.
formTips: Position forearms on top of ball, shoulder-width apart
Create straight line from head to heels
Engage core to prevent hips from sagging or piking
Look down at ball to maintain neutral neck
commonMistakes: Allowing hips to sag toward floor
Shrugging shoulders toward ears
Holding breath instead of breathing normally
Unstable arm position on ball
benefits: Intensifies core engagement due to unstable surface
Improves balance and proprioception
Enhances shoulder stability
Develops deeper core muscles for better posture
breathingPattern: Maintain normal breathing throughout the hold, avoid breath holding
preparationSteps: Place stability ball on floor with space around it
Position forearms on top of ball, shoulder-width apart
Extend legs behind you with feet hip-width apart
Engage core before lifting into full plank position

name: Fitball Plank to Pike
description: Start in a plank position with hands on floor and shins or tops of feet on stability ball. Use core strength to pike hips up while rolling the ball toward your hands, then return to plank.
formTips: Start with a strong, straight plank position
Drive hips up while pulling ball toward hands with feet
Keep legs straight throughout movement
Maintain shoulder stability (don't let shoulders collapse)
commonMistakes: Bending knees during pike
Insufficient hip height during pike
Allowing back to round excessively
Letting ball roll too far or not far enough
benefits: Intensely engages core muscles, especially upper abs
Improves shoulder strength and stability
Enhances hip mobility and hamstring flexibility
Develops total body coordination and control
breathingPattern: Exhale as you pike up, inhale as you return to plank
preparationSteps: Place stability ball on floor with space behind it
Start in high plank position with hands on floor
Place shins or tops of feet on stability ball
Create straight line from head to heels before beginning

name: Fitball Mountain Climber
description: Begin in a plank position with hands on floor and shins on stability ball. Alternate bringing knees toward chest in a running motion while maintaining ball stability.
formTips: Maintain shoulders over wrists throughout
Control the ball to prevent excessive rolling
Keep hips level during leg movements
Drive knee fully toward chest
commonMistakes: Letting hips rise or drop during movement
Allowing ball to roll uncontrollably
Moving too quickly sacrificing form
Insufficient knee drive toward chest
progressionExercises: fitball mountain climber with cross-body knee
single leg fitball plank with knee drive
benefits: Intensifies core engagement with added instability
Improves total body coordination and control
Engages more stabilizer muscles than floor version
Enhances shoulder stability while working core
breathingPattern: Maintain rhythmic breathing aligned with movement pace
preparationSteps: Place stability ball on floor with space around it
Position hands on floor in high plank position
Rest shins on stability ball with legs extended
Stabilize core and shoulders before beginning movement

name: Fitball Alternating Dead Bug
description: Lie on your back holding stability ball between extended arms and legs. Simultaneously lower opposite arm and leg, maintaining contact with the ball, then return to start and repeat with opposite limbs.
formTips: Press lower back firmly into floor throughout
Keep the ball squeezed between arms and legs
Move with control focusing on stability
Extend limbs fully without touching floor
commonMistakes: Allowing lower back to arch off floor
Losing contact with the ball
Moving too quickly without control
Holding breath during exercise
progressionExercises: double extension dead bug with ball
benefits: Enhances core stability while challenging coordination
Strengthens deep core muscles in a spine-safe position
Improves mind-muscle connection
Develops contralateral movement patterns
breathingPattern: Inhale as you extend limbs, exhale as you return to starting position
preparationSteps: Lie on your back on a mat
Hold stability ball with extended arms
Lift legs to place against ball (tabletop position)
Press lower back into floor by engaging core

name: Fitball Alternating Leg Raise
description: Lie face up with legs extended and stability ball held between ankles. Keeping legs straight, lift one leg up while the other stays on the floor, then switch legs in a controlled motion.
formTips: Press lower back firmly into floor throughout the exercise
Keep ball secure between ankles without squeezing too hard
Raise leg with control, not momentum
Keep legs straight but not locked
commonMistakes: Allowing lower back to arch off floor
Lifting both legs together instead of alternating
Dropping the ball due to insufficient control
Rushing the movement
progressionExercises: weighted ankle leg raise with ball
benefits: Strengthens lower abdominals and hip flexors
Improves leg control and coordination
Enhances inner thigh strength (adductors)
Teaches proper core engagement during leg movement
breathingPattern: Exhale as you lift leg, inhale as you lower
preparationSteps: Lie on your back on a mat
Place stability ball between ankles
Extend legs fully with ball secured
Press lower back into floor by engaging core

name: Fitball Ankle Reach
description: Lie on your back with knees bent and stability ball held between feet. Extend arms alongside body, then lift head and shoulders to reach fingers toward ankles while lifting the ball with feet.
formTips: Hold ball securely between feet (insides of ankles)
Lift shoulders and upper back off the floor
Reach fingertips toward ankles (they don't need to touch)
Keep neck in neutral position (chin slightly tucked)
commonMistakes: Pulling on neck when lifting
Losing control of the ball
Using momentum instead of core strength
Lifting feet too high causing lower back strain
progressionExercises: fitball ankle reach with leg extension
benefits: Engages upper and lower abdominals simultaneously
Improves coordination between upper and lower body
Adds challenge to basic crunch movements
Develops control and core stability
breathingPattern: Exhale as you lift and reach, inhale as you lower back down
preparationSteps: Lie on your back on a mat
Bend knees and place stability ball between feet
Position arms alongside body
Engage core before beginning the movement

name: Fitball Ball Pass
description: Lie on your back with arms extended overhead holding a stability ball. Simultaneously lift arms and legs to pass the ball from hands to feet at the top, then lower limbs and repeat in reverse.
formTips: Start with arms extended overhead and legs straight
Lift shoulders and legs simultaneously toward center
Transfer ball securely from hands to feet (or feet to hands)
Lower with control, not allowing limbs to drop quickly
commonMistakes: Allowing lower back to arch off floor
Dropping the ball during transfers
Using momentum instead of control
Incomplete range of motion
benefits: Creates complete abdominal contraction (upper and lower)
Improves coordination and control
Develops shoulder mobility and strength
Enhances body awareness and proprioception
breathingPattern: Exhale during the lifting and passing phase, inhale during lowering
preparationSteps: Lie on your back on a mat
Hold stability ball with arms extended overhead
Extend legs flat on floor
Engage core before beginning movement

name: Fitball Double Leg Hold
description: Lie on your back holding a stability ball between extended legs. Use core strength to lift legs and ball off the floor to a 45-degree angle, hold, then lower with control.
formTips: Press lower back firmly into floor throughout
Hold ball securely between ankles
Maintain a 45-degree angle or lower to reduce back strain
Keep legs straight but not locked
commonMistakes: Allowing lower back to arch off floor
Legs too high (90 degrees) reducing effectiveness
Dropping ball due to insufficient leg pressure
Holding breath during the hold
progressionExercises: fitball leg hold with small pulses
regressionExercises: fitball leg hold at higher angle
benefits: Intensely engages lower abdominal region
Strengthens hip flexors in controlled environment
Improves static strength and endurance
Teaches proper abdominal bracing during leg movements
breathingPattern: Maintain steady breathing throughout the hold - avoid breath holding
preparationSteps: Lie on your back on a mat
Place stability ball between ankles
Extend legs upward to 90 degrees initially
Press lower back firmly into floor by engaging core

name: Fitball Leg Lowering
description: Lie on your back holding a stability ball between feet. Starting with legs vertically extended, slowly lower legs and ball toward floor without touching, then raise back up.
formTips: Press lower back firmly into floor throughout entire movement
Lower legs only as far as you can maintain back contact with floor
Move slowly and with control
Keep legs straight but not locked at the knee
commonMistakes: Allowing lower back to arch off floor
Lowering legs too far
Moving too quickly, losing control
Dropping or losing the ball
regressionExercises: bent knee leg lowering with ball
benefits: Builds significant lower abdominal strength
Teaches proper core engagement with leg movement
Improves hip flexor control and strength
Enhances overall core stability
breathingPattern: Inhale as you lower legs, exhale as you lift back up
preparationSteps: Lie on your back on a mat
Place stability ball between feet/ankles
Lift legs to vertical position (90 degrees to floor)
Press lower back into floor by engaging core

name: Fitball Plank to Tuck
description: Start in a plank position with hands on floor and shins on stability ball. Pull knees toward chest while rolling the ball forward, then extend legs back to plank position.
formTips: Maintain shoulders directly over wrists throughout
Pull knees toward chest by engaging core, not just legs
Control the ball movement in both directions
Keep hips level, avoid sagging or piking
commonMistakes: Letting hips sag during plank phase
Moving shoulders back instead of keeping them over wrists
Using momentum rather than control
Incomplete knee tuck (not bringing knees close enough to chest)
benefits: Develops core strength and endurance
Improves shoulder stability and strength
Enhances total body coordination
Builds functional strength for daily activities
breathingPattern: Exhale as you tuck knees in, inhale as you extend back to plank
preparationSteps: Place stability ball on floor with space behind it
Assume high plank position with hands on floor
Rest shins on stability ball with legs extended
Engage core and set shoulders before beginning movement

name: Fitball Prayer Crunch
description: Sit on a stability ball and walk feet forward until ball is supporting mid-back. With hands pressed together in prayer position, crunch up while twisting to alternate sides.
formTips: Position ball under mid-back for proper support
Press palms together at chest height
Rotate from the ribcage, not just the arms
Keep neck neutral, don't pull with head
commonMistakes: Ball positioned too high (under neck) or too low
Insufficient rotation during crunch
Using momentum instead of control
Hunching shoulders forward
progressionExercises: fitball prayer crunch with extended arms
benefits: Targets obliques and rotational core muscles
Improves spinal mobility and rotation
Enhances balance and stability
Provides greater range of motion than floor exercises
breathingPattern: Exhale as you crunch and rotate, inhale as you return to start position
preparationSteps: Sit centered on stability ball
Walk feet forward until ball rolls under mid-back
Place hands in prayer position at chest height
Ensure feet are flat on floor, hip-width apart

name: Fitball Reverse Crunch
description: Lie on your back with stability ball held between calves and hamstrings. Engage lower abs to lift hips off floor while pulling ball toward chest, then lower with control.
formTips: Position ball securely between calves and hamstrings (back of legs)
Initiate movement from lower abs, not momentum
Lift hips slightly off the mat at top of movement
Control the descent, don't just drop legs
commonMistakes: Using momentum/swinging legs
Not lifting hips off the floor
Rolling ball too far up legs
Dropping legs too quickly on descent
progressionExercises: stability ball reverse crunch with hip lift
benefits: Targets lower portion of rectus abdominis
Reduces strain on neck and upper back
Provides proprioceptive feedback with ball
Teaches proper lower abdominal activation
breathingPattern: Exhale as you lift legs/hips, inhale as you lower
preparationSteps: Lie on your back on a mat
Place stability ball between calves and hamstrings
Position arms at sides for support
Engage core before beginning movement

name: Fitball Tuck
description: Sit on a stability ball with feet on floor. Roll backward until mid-back is on ball, then pull knees toward chest in a tucking motion and extend back out.
formTips: Start with ball supporting mid-back
Keep head and shoulders on ball during movement
Pull knees directly toward chest
Extend legs without locking knees
commonMistakes: Lifting head and shoulders off ball
Using momentum rather than control
Insufficient knee lift/tuck
Rolling too far on ball losing stability
benefits: Engages core while supported on ball
Improves hip flexor coordination with abdominals
Enhances balance and stability
Provides greater range of motion than floor exercises
breathingPattern: Exhale as you tuck knees in, inhale as you extend legs
preparationSteps: Sit centered on stability ball
Walk feet forward until ball rolls under mid-back
Place hands lightly on ball beside body for support
Position feet hip-width apart on floor
